poem:
"Strangers, Speed, and Digital Love"

No beauty in swipes made 
upon tempered glass.
Yet, Lilian returns—
to faceless profiles,
brief, listless talks,
deleting, reinstalling,
a cycle unbroken.

In noisy clubs,
dusty taverns,
no solace found.
Amid unnatural speed,
where can love be profound—
but in the quiet whisper of her heart,
longing for connection,
in this tangled digital art.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Go and talk to strangers – it’s fun’: why speed dating is having a moment Lilian no longer knows how many times she’s deleted all the dating apps from her phone. Somehow, she always reinstalls them.While she says she hates “the apps”, as they are now known (begrudgingly or affectionately, depending on your success), going clubbing or hanging around at a pub is “not where you meet people”. Lilian says dating apps have made romance". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
